awd_titl_txt: NSF INCLUDES DDLP: Fostering Engineering Identity and Support Structures to Promote Entry and Persistence in Engineering for First-Generation Students
awd_abstract_narration:
Arizona State University's Ira A. Fulton Schools of Engineering with the Maricopa County Community Colleges District and K-12 school districts along with industry partners, Honeywell, Intel, and Texas Instruments, and the Helios Education Foundation will implement an NSF Design and Development Launch Pilot to address the broadening participation objectives of enhancing entry and persistence of underrepresented groups in engineering. This alliance will identify and develop effective mechanisms to impact entry and persistence in engineering at scale and to expand the effort for the region, serving as a model for Arizona and other universities nationally. Diversity is often seen as a valuable commodity for fostering innovation and creativity in engineering, and extant theoretical and empirical literature provides evidence of the importance a diversified engineering workforce can have to spark scientific and technological innovation to solve complex problems. Nationally, there is a consistent shortage of available diverse engineers and scientists, which is believed to compromise the country's ability to sustain its leadership position as a global force. This project will create engineering pathways for underrepresented groups and identify and develop effective mechanisms that impact these students' entry and persistence in engineering. 

A total of 500 high school students, 100 2-year college students, and 200 four-year college students will participate in the project. The research measures will focus on students' academic/career awareness and interest in engineering and the degree to which students develop a strong identity and affinity for engineering. It is expected that the alliance affiliates will develop into adaptive systems that respond to needs of first-generation students at various pathway junctures. This project has the potential to transform educational experiences and support systems for first-generation students.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
The Engineers from Day One Alliance has made progress in addressing pathways for first-generation-to-university, women, and under-represented ethnic minority student entry and persistence in undergraduate engineering programs at Arizona State University (ASU). Major collaborators include the Maricopa Community Colleges, K-12 school districts, industry partners, and other community organizations.

Intellectual Merit:
For many first-generation university students, transition to university settings includes developing the confidence to become successful engineering students and envision future possible selves as engineers. Strategies were designed to foster the many related factors that influence identity development by creating a sense of belonging in students; generating confidence, support, and agency for academic success; advocacy for engineering as socially and personally relevant; and engagement in engineering activities beyond coursework. Near peers from the university, alumni, and industry were enlisted to encourage students' evolving engineering identities. Alliance members studied and revise pilot mechanisms, institutionalized mechanisms such as Engineering Projects in Community Service as an engineering pathways program for high schools and the Engineering Futures (FSE) scholarship and engineering persistence program for undergraduate engineering students. These efforts were scaled up to include the Maricopa Community Colleges and K-12 districts. Data were collected to inform the creation of a model for how to more effectively broaden participation using engineering identity development as the framework to interest first generation students and promote persistence. This innovative approach seeks to challenge traditional views of engineering as perceived by students and families. It aims to confront stereotypes about who can become an engineer, and will focus on making engineering socially and personally relevant to the individual. The collective alliance has the potential to transform institutionally engendered identities to be inclusive of the multiple and mutable engineering identities. By anchoring student experiences in engineering as essentially human centered, the goal is to show how deliberately designed experiences impact identity development across the K-12 to university continuum.

Through an iterative design process, social media graphics were designed for an engineering messaging campaign to promote engineering. These are available at the Engineers from Day One website: https://includes.engineering.asu.edu/

Broader Impacts:
Alliance institutions have developed into adaptive systems that respond to the
common goal of broadening participation in engineering for first generation students, women, under-represented minorities, and those with socio-economic need. Shared data between academic collaborators spanning the K-12 and higher education sector has made it possible to identity and deliver engineering awareness efforts at targeted populations in schools. Strategic new partners such as the Girl Scouts of Arizona have helped enhance the Alliance's reach to new audiences.

The Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program curriculum training has been offered to 77 middle and high school educators from 51 schools. These partners have collaborated with 66 non-profit partners over time. 65% of these schools are Title I schools.

The Young Engineers Shape the World (YESW) program has had participants from 26 school districts, 15 charter schools, and 3 private schools.

The Maricopa to ASU Pathways Program (MAPP) has proven to be a key aspect in enhancing entry of transfer students into engineering programs at ASU. Number of Maricopa Community Colleges students completing MAPP agreements increased from 140 in Spring 2017 to 396 in Spring 2020 and 273 in Fall 2017 to 704 in Fall 2020.

Facilitated visits of students from Maricopa and other colleges (e.g., Cochise College, Eastern Arizona College, Central Arizona College) to ASU Engineering programs for the Fulton Undergraduate Research Initiative (FURI) and the Innovation Showcase along with interactions with academic advisors have helped demystify the transfer process. 

The Engineers from Day One Alliance aims to continue to grow and further develop these broadening participation efforts.


Last Modified: 10/01/2021
Modified by: Tirupalavanam G Ganesh
